section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?

section-block.rac_book_title_hed_theme_4_one-line: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?
section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague
section-block.rac_book_summary: Oh, no! What happens when a dinosaur gets the flu? What should a dinosaur do to get well?

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64879-9. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague. Text copyright © 2003 by Jane Yolen. Illustrations copyright © 2003 by Mark Teague. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Ff, Ll, Mm Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Practice saying the beginning sounds in fish, fox, ladybug, leaf, milk, and mitten.
Sing “I Think I’m Going to Sneeze” to the tune of “Farmer in the Dell,” “I think I’m going to sneeze. (2x). So please pass the tissues, Ha-choo, Ha-choo, Ha-choo.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? written by Jane Yolen and illustrated by Mark Teague.
Pablo loves reading narratives about staying healthy. Let’s find out what happens when dinosaurs get sick.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happens when a dinosaur gets the flu?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does a dinosaur whimper and whine between sneezes?
Let’s whimper and whine like a dinosaur.
What does the dinosaur do with its dirty tissue? Where should he put the dirty tissue?
Why are the letters on this page all written in uppercase? Do you think it means the dinosaur is being noisy or quiet?
Why do you think the doctor wants the dinosaur to open wide?
Do you see the letter m on this page? Let’s make the sound the letter m makes.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happens when a dinosaur gets the flu?
section.rac_body-text: Give children one moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Write and read short sentences about what happens when a dinosaur gets sick.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why is it good to use a tissue when you sneeze?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children should be taught that active listening involves more than just their ears. It also requires their eyes and feelings. Encourage children to listen actively by asking each other questions about the book and about times when they were sick. What did they do to get better?

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Move Carefully Through Surroundings
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a conversation about the concept of personal space. Call a child to hep you demonstrate how you sometimes have to share your space. Show how you move around each other without touching. Ask children to suggest words to use if someone is in their space (Please move) or if they are in someone’s space (Please excuse me).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder. We are going to see how the dinosaurs move carefully when we revisit the book How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?, by Jane Yolen, illustrated by Mark Teague.
Clifford is very big, but he tries to move very carefully and not touch or bump into anyone.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to share their responses.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who do you see on the cover? Let’s share our ideas and talk about what is happening? (MB)
How can you tell that this dinosaur is feeling grumpy? Let’s share ideas about why he is feeling and acting that way? (MB)
Can you spot an uppercase L on this page?
How can you tell that this dinosaur is doing a good job sharing space with the people in the doctor’s office? (MB)
What are the people doing with their hands so they don’t disturb each other? (MB)
How can you tell that this dinosaur is behaving well?
section.rac_body-text: Point out how some sentences in the book begin and end.

To help children understand the idea of moving carefully through their surroundings, set up an obstacle course. Ask children to pretend that each of the obstacles is a person, and they have to walk around the people without touching or bumping into them. It might be fun to do this to music, if available. Depending on the group, you may want the children to take turns, choose a few at a time to walk, or have the whole group move at once. You may also determine the speed at which the children move.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about what happens when a dinosaur visits the doctor.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers may not have developed much impulse control. When they feel something, they are likely to act on it. This may include snatching a toy away from another child if they want to play with it or getting upset when told they need to wait. Encourage children to respect one another’s boundaries and to be patient. (Kochanska, 2000.)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about what children can do to stay healthy. Encourage them to think about eating healthy food, getting exercise, washing their hands, and using tissues.
Remind children that two words that rhyme end with the same sound, such as hat and mat. Ask children to name words that rhyme with get, well, and soon.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? written by Jane Yolen and illustrated by Mark Teague.
Pablo enjoys reading about how dinosaurs get well soon when they get the flu.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:What can a dinosaur do to get well soon?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the doctor want to do to help the dinosaur get well? Let’s share and talk about your ideas about how to behave when you visit the doctor. (MB)
What does the dinosaur do to help himself feel better?
Does the dinosaur take its medicine? Why do you think the dad is smiling?
The dinosaur whispers, “Good night.” How do our voices sound when we whisper? Let’s all whisper “good night.” Now that we have said “good night” we can let the dinosaur get some rest!

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: What can a dinosaur do to get well soon?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: A dinosaur can take its medicine.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen as you work together to write about getting better soon. Encourage children to use lowercase and uppercase letters. Point out the end punctuation in sentences.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Should the dinosaur drink lots of juice?
The dinosaur should drink lots of j____ (juice).
The dinosaur should drink lots of juice.
Why is it good for the dinosaur to rest?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Repetition and encouragement are the keys to teaching children about personal hygiene. Whether it’s washing their hands or blowing their nose, be sure to remind children to take care of themselves. After they have done the correct action, give children praise.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to share ideas about how to stay healthy. Ideas may include eating healthy foods, doing exercise, and getting lots of rest.
Use this finger play. “This is my right hand, I raise it up high. This is my left hand, I raise it to the sky. Right and left hand, I roll them around. Right and left hand, tap, tap, tap.”

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Keep Your Hands Clean. We’ll sing a song, and then we’ll see steps to follow to keep our hands clean.
Pablo loves to read informational posters about staying healthy.
How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? and Keep Your Hands Clean are both about what we should do to stay well. Let’s listen and make connections!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How can we stay healthy?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text of the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read together and discuss the poster about washing hands.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is the first thing to do?
You need soap to clean your hands. Act out how you get your hands soapy.
Show how you scrub your hands with soap. What else can you scrub with soap?
What happens when you rinse your hands?
Show your neighbors how to dry your hands.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: After the dinosaurs get well, what do you think they should do to stay well?

section.rac_body-text: In pairs, children will teach a doll how to wash its hands. One child tells and shows the doll while the partner checks, then they switch roles.
Provide a writing prompt about when and how children should wash their hands. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Practice, individual or with classmates, is important for multilingual learners. Make sure there are regular opportunities to practice and develop both language and understanding of content, such as taking care of one’s self. Practice should have specific learning goals with feedback that helps learning.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_5: Sing and Act Out Healthy Habits
section-block.rac_body-text: To the tune of “Mulberry Bush,“ engage children in singing and acting out good health habits. Use the following lines: “This is the way we wash our hands. This is the way we comb our hair. This is the way we brush our teeth. This is the way we eat good food. This is the way we exercise.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book How Do Dinosaurs Get Well Soon? by Jane Yolen and Mark Teague.

Remember, this narrative is about what happens when dinosaurs get the flu. It’s a funny book because of the way the dinosaurs act when they have the flu. Pablo loves being healthy—and reading funny books.
This week we read about dinosaurs who have the flu. As I reread the book, I want you to think about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What might children do if they get the flu?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you notice something funny about the dinosaurs and the parents who are taking care of them?
Act out how you think a dinosaur sounds when he sneezes. Let’s whimper and whine between each atchoo!
Pretend you are the dinosaur’s mom or dad. What would you say to get him to take his medicine?
Let’s pretend we are taking the dinosaur to the doctor. What can we say or do to get the dinosaur to the doctor? Let’s share our ideas and talk about what we might do? (MB)
Talk and share ideas about how the dinosaur acts now. How does his mom feel?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Invite children to Turn and Talk about the guiding question:
What might children do if they get the flu?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible ­responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They can drink lots of juice.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about something they do when

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why is it good to snuggle in bed if you are sick?
It’s good to snuggle in bed so you can r____ (rest).
It’s good to snuggle in bed so you can rest.
What do you do when you have a cold or the flu?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When Turn and Talk is used, all children have a chance to share their thinking. Verbalizing thinking scaffolds their understanding and provides talk at a peer level. As an oral language strategy, it provides children with a scaffolded time to share thinking and formulate thoughts.
